headline: Australian election 2025 polls tracker: Labor v Coalition latest opinion poll results | Australian politics | The Guardian
context: As the 2025 Australian federal election approaches, political polls are coming thick and fast. This page will be regularly updated so you can track who is polling up, how the independents are faring and how the parties stand with different demographics.
Labor is leading in our poll model

annotations.paragraph: Showing the estimated two-party preferred (2pp) and primary vote ranges for the Coalition, Labor, other parties and independents and the Greens. Last updated 3 May 2025
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about the poll results and their update date.

annotations.paragraph: This first chart is based on a poll averaging model developed by political scientists at the University of Sydney. It factors in sample sizes, previous results and “house effects” (bias towards a party) of each pollster.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the methodology behind the poll results, which is relevant to understanding the data.

annotations.paragraph: There is a lot of uncertainty in political polling and modelling and these charts show a range that likely contains the support for each party. You can read more in our methodology at the end of the page.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the uncertainty in polling, which is relevant to interpreting the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: How the parties are doing relative to the last election
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a comparison to the last election, which is relevant to understanding current poll standings.

annotations.paragraph: Showing the ‘swing’ to and away from each party, being the change in estimated median primary vote compared to their result at the last election. Last updated 3 May 2025
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on changes in party support since the last election.

annotations.paragraph: The next shows a timeline of the two-party preferred (2pp) vote since 2022:
annotations.reason: This introduces a timeline of polling data, which is relevant to tracking election polls.

annotations.paragraph: Tracking the two party preferred support for Labor and the Coalition
annotations.reason: This provides information on the focus of the poll tracking, which is relevant to the election polls.

annotations.paragraph: Circles show the two party preferred support for each political group in individual polls. The shaded area indicates the credibility interval* for the averaged 2pp. Events labelled are to provide context only, and do not necessarily indicate events that resulted in change in support. Last updated 3 May 2025
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains how the poll data is visually represented and provides the latest update, which is relevant.

annotations.paragraph: 40%45%50%55%60%Mar '25Apr '25May '2503 May49.7 - 53.1% 49.7 - 53.1% 46.9 - 50.3% 46.9 - 50.3% Labor wins 2022 electionVoice Referendum date announcedVoice Referendum heldScott Morrison revealed to have multiple ministriesConsumer Price Index peaks at 7.8%Peter Dutton names seven potential nuclear power sites Jan '23Jan '24Jan '25
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific polling data and historical context, which is relevant to understanding the election polls.

annotations.paragraph: Looking at two-party support alone can obscure one of the biggest stories of the last election: almost a third of votes were for independents and other parties.
annotations.reason: This highlights the significance of independent and minor party support, which is relevant to the election context.

annotations.paragraph: The 68.5% primary votes share for Labor and the Coalition is an all time low and the continuation of a steady decline since the two parties claimed 98% of votes in 1951.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context and current data on the primary vote share for Labor and the Coalition.

annotations.paragraph: The chart below shows the primary votes for Labor, the Coalition, Greens and others/independents. It is based on the same model as our main tracker, starting with the vote share at the last election. Use the drop-down menu to see what has changed over different periods since the election.
annotations.reason: Describes a chart feature rather than providing new information about the election.

annotations.paragraph: Tracking primary vote support as of 3 May 2025
annotations.reason: Provides a specific date for tracking primary vote support, relevant to the election timeline.

annotations.paragraph: Showing the estimated primary vote for each party since:
annotations.reason: Incomplete information that does not contribute to understanding the election results.

annotations.paragraph: To get a sample that reflects the nation at large, pollsters collect a lot of demographic information, including age, sex, location and education.
annotations.reason: General information about polling methodology, not specific to the election results.

annotations.paragraph: Polling companies occasionally release two-party preferred measures for these sub-demographics.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on polling methods related to sub-demographics.

annotations.paragraph: The following charts use simple rolling averages to try to find the underlying trend in two-party support. There has been no adjustment for sample size, house effects, weighting or release date.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the methodology behind the charts, which is relevant to understanding the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The first shows support by the age group of the respondent.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a specific demographic breakdown, which is relevant to the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The next chart groups respondents by education – those with no tertiary education, those with a Tafe or technical education, and those with university education.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on how respondents are grouped by education, relevant to the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The chart below groups respondents by sex – male or female. As the numbers are rolling averages, they will not always add up to 100.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes another demographic breakdown, which is relevant to the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The final demographic category is state. Data is not available for all states, largely because of their size. Tasmania, for instance, makes up about 2% of the population. A representative sample of 1,000 Australians would have far too few Tasmanians to provide a robust estimate.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the limitations of polling data by state, which is relevant to understanding the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The final table shows the two-party preferred share for all of the polls that feed into our models.
annotations.reason: This paragraph indicates the presence of a table but does not provide new information or analysis itself.

annotations.paragraph: What does Guardian Australia’s poll tracker actually do?
annotations.reason: This is a heading and does not provide any information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Most Australian political polls have a sample size of a little over 1,000 respondents. There’s only so much any one of these polls can tell you. And the fluctuations between polls and for the same pollster across time can often just be statistical noise.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the limitations and variability of polling data, which is relevant to interpreting the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The poll tracker pools all of the polls using a model developed by political scientists at the University of Sydney. It assumes political intentions yesterday are similar to today and today is like tomorrow, but with small random changes.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the methodology behind the poll tracker, which is relevant to understanding how the poll results are aggregated.

annotations.paragraph: The model starts, and is anchored to, the actual 2022 election results. And it assumes polling organisations’ bias is fixed. This is what was observed in previous elections, such as in 2019.
annotations.reason: Provides context on how the polling model is constructed and its assumptions.

annotations.paragraph: Why does the polling model draw a line below Labor’s actual poll numbers (the circles) while the Coalition’s line goes right through their polling numbers?
annotations.reason: Introduces a question about the polling model's representation of data.

annotations.paragraph: As noted above - the model begins with the last election results and assumes voting intentions evolve over time. The model indicates the polls are overestimating the Labor vote. This pattern was also observed between the 2016 and 2019 elections. In that period the model was correcting for the pollsters’ systematic bias between those elections.
annotations.reason: Explains the model's adjustments and historical context of polling biases.

annotations.paragraph: Is the Guardian Australia tracker a prediction of who is going to win the election?
annotations.reason: Introduces a question about the purpose of the tracker.

annotations.paragraph: No. It is simply an aggregation of the public polls. It is a snapshot in time of people’s stated voting intentions, which can change.
annotations.reason: Clarifies the purpose of the tracker as an aggregation of polls, not a prediction.

annotations.paragraph: Why have we changed the poll tracker format/What is the range we are showing?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a heading and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: Every time we update the poll tracker the model runs thousands of simulations. The first version of this page only showed the average of these simulations – a single number. Our charts did include a credibility interval - sometimes also known as a margin of error. But highlighting just one number implied greater certainty than the data warranted.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the methodology behind the poll tracker, which is relevant to understanding the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The refresh to the page puts the emphasis on the credibility interval. We are using a 95% credibility interval - there is a 95% chance that the actual support for each party is inside this range. We are aiming to emphasise that there is a degree of uncertainty to both the results of any one poll and an aggregate of polls.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides important context about the credibility interval used in the poll tracker.

annotations.paragraph: Why are we using a rolling average for some things instead of the same poll average model?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a heading and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: The demographic data is not consistent. Not every pollster releases demographic breakdowns, and the ones that do don’t necessarily release it with each poll. There can be months in between releases for some demographic variables, such as voting intention by level of education.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the challenges with demographic data, which is relevant to understanding the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: But this data is still useful and should be included in some form. Given we can’t model the data in the same way, we are instead using a simple rolling average to track it over time.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the methodology used to track polling data, which is relevant to understanding the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: Notes and methods
annotations.reason: This is a section header and does not provide any substantive information.

annotations.paragraph: The main poll tracker is based on work by Dr Luke Mansillo and Prof Simon Jackman. You can find their paper here.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides attribution for the poll tracker, which is relevant to the credibility of the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The model in different disciplines is called a hidden Markov model or a state space model and employs a Kalman filter algorithm that uses a series of measurements over time, including statistical noise and other inaccuracies, to produce estimates.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides technical details about the model used, which is relevant to understanding the poll tracking methodology.

annotations.paragraph: These types of models are often used in fields such as robotics, economics and medicine to create estimates from noisy measurements.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general information about the use of models in other fields, which is not directly relevant to the election poll results.

annotations.paragraph: Each newly published poll is treated as a new measurement, with the model factoring in new data in the context of what has come before.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains how new poll data is integrated into the model, which is relevant to understanding the poll tracking process.

annotations.paragraph: The model begins with (is anchored to) the vote share for each party at the last federal election.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the baseline used in the poll model, which is relevant to the poll tracking process.

annotations.paragraph: Only polls with a defined sampling procedure, reported sample size and fielding dates have been included in our dataset. Polls are sliced over the days that they are in the field.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the criteria for including polls in the dataset, which is relevant to the accuracy and reliability of the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: Sample sizes are adjusted to account for non-response, with effective sample size fed into the model.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes how sample sizes are adjusted, which is relevant to the methodology of the poll model.

annotations.paragraph: The model calculates house effects for each pollster dynamically, by finding systematic differences to what would be expected, given the current average.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains how the model accounts for pollster biases, which is relevant to understanding the poll results.

annotations.paragraph: The two-party preferred vote is adjusted to remove unknowns or nonresponses, leaving only Labor and Coalition shares.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about how the poll results are calculated.

annotations.paragraph: The model is run 1,000 times for each update
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives relevant details about the methodology of the poll model.
